content: Looking for a culture fit sounds like a euphemism for discriminatory practices. It usually means that outstanding applicants — and maybe even the best applicants get rejected simply because they’re the wrong race, age or gender, etc. It would be nice if more companies were mature enough to look past culture fit and at culture contribution instead. But I’m not sure how many companies are ready to shift their thinking about this issue. There’s a closed mindedness prevalent among hiring managers that needs to be overcome. After all you can benefit by collaborating with someone even if they don’t like the same baseball team as you do. And some friendly sports debates in the office could even be fun. Value fit is good — if as the other commenter says — the company actually practices its stated values.
